concept.title: Weight and Balance
concept.shortdesc: The day when a pilot flew by guesswork is past. One by one the decisions that were made by intuition, hunches, and guesswork have been taken over by an orderly system based on knowledge and understanding. Invariably this has resulted in greater safety and operating efficiency.

fig.title: Weight and Balance
fig.desc: Image presenting a heavy weight near a fulcrum, and a distant, smaller weight balancing things out on the other side of the lever arm.

image.alt: Getting the balance right is crucial when flying a .

conbody.p: In the loading of heavy bombers this is especially true. Ever-changing tactical requirements, calling for more and more complex combinations of cargo, fuel, crew, and armament, have made any but precise, accurate methods too dangerous to consider. This need to get the utmost in efficiency from every flight highlights the need for precise control of weight and balance.
Improper loading, at best, cuts down the efficiency of an airplane. Maneuverability, rate of climb, speed, and ceiling suffer greatly.
At its worst, it may mean failure to complete a flight, and sometimes failure even to start a flight, in most cases with a loss of life and destruction of valuable equipment.

fig.title: Balancing the weight distribution across a
fig.desc: Image of an airplane balanced on a fulcrum near where the wings would be, showing that 3lbs at the front of a plane can be offset by 1lb at the back.

fig.title: Structural failure
fig.desc: Image of a balance that is broken at the fulcrum due to two heavy weights at either end.

image.alt: Do not overload the , or structural failure may result.

ol.li: Increases length of the takeoff run.
Lowers the angle and rate of climb.
Increases fuel consumption for a given speed.

section.title: Center of Gravity Too Far Forward

fig.title: Nose heavy
fig.desc: Image of a balance with a heavy weight on the left side forcing up a small weight to the right; below an image of an airplane with its nose pitched down.

image.alt: Ensure that the is not nose heavy.

ol.li: Causes unstable, nose-down tendencies when flaps are lowered.
Increases difficulty in raising nose on landing.
Increases pilot strain in instrument flying.
Dangerous if tail structure is damaged.

section.title: Center of Gravity Too Far Aft

fig.title: Tail heavy
fig.desc: Image of a balance with a heavy weight on the right side forcing up a small weight to the left; below an image of an airplane with its nose pitched up.

image.alt: Ensure that the is not tail heavy.

ol.li: Increases pilot strain in instrument flying.
Dangerous if tail structure is damaged.
